maml:description.maml:para: Gets information about the available audio analyzers.
The Get-AudioAnalyzerInfo cmdlet gets objects that describe the audio analyzers currently loaded and available for use with the Measure-AudioFile cmdlet.
The Export-AudioFile cmdlet creates a new audio file using the specified encoder.
The file extension will be selected automatically and should not be included. If this parameter is omitted, the name will be the same as the source audio file.
Indicates that existing files should be replaced.
The file extension will be selected automatically and should not be included. If this parameter is omitted, the name will be the same as the source audio file.
Indicates that existing files should be replaced.
Gets an object that represents an audio file or album's cover art.
The Get-AudioCoverArt cmdlet gets objects that represent cover art. Cover art can be applied to and extracted from audio files when supported by the audio format.
Specifies the path to an item. This cmdlet gets the item at the specified location. Wildcards are permitted. This parameter is required, but the parameter name ("Path") is optional.
Use a dot (.) to specify the current location. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all the items in the current location.

Specifies a path to the item. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of LiteralPath is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.
Specifies the path to an item. This cmdlet gets the item at the specified location. Wildcards are permitted. This parameter is required, but the parameter name ("Path") is optional.
Use a dot (.) to specify the current location. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all the items in the current location.

Specifies a path to the item. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of LiteralPath is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.

Specifies a path to the item. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of LiteralPath is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.
This is an alias of the LiteralPath parameter.
Specifies the path to an item. This cmdlet gets the item at the specified location. Wildcards are permitted. This parameter is required, but the parameter name ("Path") is optional.
Use a dot (.) to specify the current location. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all the items in the current location.
Gets information about the available audio encoders.
The Get-AudioEncoderInfo cmdlet gets objects that describe the audio encoders currently loaded and available for use with the Export-AudioFile cmdlet.
The Export-AudioFile cmdlet creates a new audio file using the specified encoder.
The file extension will be selected automatically and should not be included. If this parameter is omitted, the name will be the same as the source audio file.
Indicates that existing files should be replaced.
The file extension will be selected automatically and should not be included. If this parameter is omitted, the name will be the same as the source audio file.
Indicates that existing files should be replaced.
Gets an object that represents an audio file.
The Get-AudioFile cmdlet gets objects that represent audio files. Audio files expose metadata, and can be manipulated in various ways by the other AudioWorks cmdlets.
Specifies the path to an item. This cmdlet gets the item at the specified location. Wildcards are permitted. This parameter is required, but the parameter name ("Path") is optional.
Use a dot (.) to specify the current location. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all the items in the current location.

Specifies a path to the item. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of LiteralPath is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.
Specifies the path to an item. This cmdlet gets the item at the specified location. Wildcards are permitted. This parameter is required, but the parameter name ("Path") is optional.
Use a dot (.) to specify the current location. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all the items in the current location.

Specifies a path to the item. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of LiteralPath is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.

Specifies a path to the item. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of LiteralPath is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.
This is an alias of the LiteralPath parameter.
Specifies the path to an item. This cmdlet gets the item at the specified location. Wildcards are permitted. This parameter is required, but the parameter name ("Path") is optional.
Use a dot (.) to specify the current location. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all the items in the current location.
The Measure-AudioFile cmdlet performs analysis on an audio file, then stores these measurements as metadata.
Specifies the type of analysis to perform.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the type of analysis to perform.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
The Rename-AudioFile cmdlet renames audio files.
The file extension will be selected automatically and should not be included.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Indicates that existing files should be replaced.
The file extension will be selected automatically and should not be included.
Indicates that existing files should be replaced.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Gets information about an audio file.
The Get-AudioInfo cmdlet gets information about audio files. This consists of immutable information that can't be changed without re-encoding the file.
Clears one or more metadata fields on an audio file.
The Clear-AudioMetadata cmdlet clears one or more metadata fields. Note that these changes are not persisted to disk unless followed by a call to Save-AudioMetadata.
If no metadata fields are specified, all fields are cleared.
Clears the day of the month.
Clears the track peak, album peak, track gain and album gain.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Clears the day of the month.
Clears the track peak, album peak, track gain and album gain.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Gets metadata describing an audio file.
The Get-AudioMetadata cmdlet gets information about audio files. This consists of fields that can be modified and optionally persisted to disk using other cmdlets.
Saves an audio file's metadata to disk.
The Save-AudioMetadata cmdlet persists changes to an audio file's metadata. Depending on the file extension, various optional parameters may be available.
Specifies the metadata format to use.
This is normally selected automatically based on the file extension. Explicitly specifying the format enables any dynamic parameters that are format-specific.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the metadata format to use.
This is normally selected automatically based on the file extension. Explicitly specifying the format enables any dynamic parameters that are format-specific.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Sets one or more metadata fields on an audio file.
The Set-AudioMetadata cmdlet changes the value of one or more metadata fields. Note that these changes are not persisted to disk unless followed by a call to Save-AudioMetadata.
Sets the day of the month.
Should be a number between 1 and 31.
Should be a number between 1 and 12.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Sets the day of the month.
Should be a number between 1 and 31.
Should be a number between 1 and 12.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Gets information about the available metadata encoders.
The Get-AudioMetadataEncoderInfo cmdlet gets objects that describe the metadata encoders currently loaded and available for use with the Save-AudioMetadata cmdlet.
